This cheat sheet covers some fundamental aspects of p5.js. For more detailed information and examples, refer to the official p5.js documentation: p5.js Reference.

docs.title: Introducing P5js
docs.text:
For full documentation visit p5js.org

p5.js is a JavaScript library for creative coding, with a focus on making coding accessible and inclusive for artists, designers, educators, beginners, and anyone else!

docs.title: What is JavaScript?
docs.text:
For full documentation visit Javascript

JavaScript is a programming language that allows you to implement complex functionalities on web pages. It integrates a lot of front-end functionalities (client-side, i.e. how the website looks) but can be also used for back-end when used with a runtime such as Node.js

docs.title: Some Terminology
docs.text: Syntax Description Sketch These are used to refer to quick iterations of small creative coding programs written in P5js. Programming Sketchbook This is a collection of P5js sketches. Just like with a normal sketchbook, the idea is that you work out a variety of different ideas in code and present them as a collection. HTML/CSS The other main languages, other than JS, used on the web are HTML and CSS. HTML is used to define the content while CSS is used for the visual output. Canvas A canvas is an HTML element that is intended for drawing graphics in web pages. Although it can produce other kinds of output, such as sound, P5js mostly uses the canvas element for its visual output. Processing P5js is a translation of an older creative coding environment called processing into JS.  Code written in Processing looks similar to code written in P5js and most of the functions are named the same.

docs.title: Understanding the Sketch
docs.text: There are two function declarations for the 'skeleton' program: the setup() and the draw().

docs.title: The setup() Function
docs.text: The setup() function is like the program's kickoff. It's called once when the program starts and is used to set up the basics, such as the screen size, background color, and loading images or fonts. You only have one setup() in your program, and it runs only at the beginning. Any variables you create inside setup() can't be used in other parts of the program, like the draw() function.

docs.title: The draw() Function
docs.text:
When does draw() run? - The draw() function runs continuously after the setup() function. - It keeps executing the code inside its block until the program stops or until you use noLoop() to explicitly stop it.

Special case with noLoop(): - If you use noLoop() in setup(), draw() will still run once before stopping.

Controlling draw(): - You control draw() using functions like noLoop(), redraw(), and loop(). - noLoop() stops draw() from running continuously. - redraw() makes draw() run once. - loop() makes draw() run continuously again.

Setting the frame rate: - You can control how many times draw() executes in a second using the frameRate() function.

Base Setup Code 

function setup() {
  createCanvas(400, 400);
}

function draw() {
  background(220);
}

Extended Sample Code 

let yPos = 0;
function setup() {
  // setup() runs once
  frameRate(30);
}
function draw() {
  // draw() loops forever, until stopped
  background(204);
  yPos = yPos - 1;
  if (yPos < 0) {
    yPos = height;
  }
  line(0, yPos, width, yPos);
}

docs.title: The Canvas Origin
docs.text:
In p5.js, the canvas has a coordinate system to represent space. The starting point, or origin (0, 0), is at the top-left corner of the canvas.

The Coordinate System The canvas coordinate system is described using ordered pairs, (x, y), where the x coordinate (horizontal) is the distance from the left edge of the canvas and the y coordinate (vertical) is the distance from the top edge of the canvas.
